text: In the beginning, there was HTML, hypertext markup language, a way to give plain old text some structure.
Back then, we had no phones, just dirt roads, radio songs, and big dreams.
Then came the web browsers. They gave that structure a face. The web got its backbone.
And with that, the modern internet was born, a place where every document had its place.
[coughing]
Then came Google, smart kid on the block, learned to read that structure, index it and
make it searchable.
Suddenly the web wasn't a library anymore.
It was an oracle.
And then, chat GPT, trained on that same searchable web, blogs, emails, recipes, arguments, dreams, all scooped up and
learned.
But you know, while all this was happening, the world outside was changing.
The fields grew quiet.
The rivers, a little warmer.
The trees got fewer. the bugs got rarer.
There was structure for the web, but not for the wild.
No HTML for the chirp of a night jaw, no CSS for a mossy rock, no Java script to animate
the leopards linking through the nigguries. Much of our knowledge of nature, it's stuck,
and PDFs, field notes, shape files, old photos,
dusty memories.
But what if we had an internet for nature?
Imagine that, a structured, open Facebook
for the oak trees,
technology not built for ads, but built for the planet.
I'd ask it about the Himalayas, about polar bears, about the endangered XYZ trees the rainforests
need to survive.
And maybe, just maybe, we'd remember how to listen,
not just to the web, but to the world.
